items.title: Meet the B.C. residents hosting whale detection devices on their properties
items.summary_auto: From infrared thermal cameras to hydrophones, these B.C. residents offered up space on their properties as researchers look to help safeguard marine mammals.

items.title: Stolen Nutcracker set recovered, Ontario ballet says
items.summary_auto: Jörgen Dance's artistic director and CEO says the moving truck containing set and backdrops, which was allegedly stolen in Etobicoke Monday, has been found. The company had planned to go ahead with its Tuesday show in Burlington regardless.

items.title: Endangered barn owl makes 'extremely rare' appearance in Calgary
items.summary_auto: The barn owl, one of Canada's most endangered owls, isn't native to Alberta and is considered extremely rare anywhere in the province, which is why wildlife photographers were shocked when one made a surprise appearance in a Calgary park.

items.title: Caregiver wants apology after off-duty RCMP officer arrested woman with intellectual delay
Prestigious Chicago beer brewing school relocating to Montreal amid U.S. regulatory changes
N.B. government says none of 40 Sisson Mine conditions met so far
items.summary_auto: Environmentalists are concerned that the conditions for approval of the Sisson Mine north of Fredericton were too weak when they were issued in 2015, and now many are a decade out of date.

items.title: Russian attacks kill at least 6 in Ukraine, as U.S. and Russia diplomats hold talks in Abu Dhabi
items.summary_auto: Russia launched a wave of attacks on Ukraine on Tuesday, killing at least six people in overnight strikes that hit city buildings and energy infrastructure, while a Ukrainian attack in southern Russia killed three people and damaged homes, authorities said. Meanwhile talks aimed at putting a halt to the hostilities were set to take place in Europe and Abu Dhabi.

items.title: Tracking Palestinian, Israeli deaths since the Gaza ceasefire went into effect
items.summary_auto: In the first six weeks since Israel and Palestinian militant group Hamas reached a truce deal aimed at ending their two-year war, Israeli attacks in Gaza have been reported almost daily.

items.title: How Dancing with the Stars made all the right moves with Gen Z
items.summary_auto: Dancing with the Stars recently celebrated its 20th anniversary — but that's not why it's been the talk of Instagram, TikTok, Twitter and, yes, water coolers everywhere this season. Blending nostalgia with a new kind of stardom, the show has successfully reimagined the dance competition for a new generation.

items.title: Hamilton is 'ready for the spotlight' with 2026 Juno Awards coming in March, says mayor
items.summary_auto: Coming off the success of Paul McCartney playing the first concert at TD Coliseum Friday night, Hamilton is getting ready to host another major music event.

items.title: Some wins for multilateralism at the G20 — and big questions about its long-term future
items.summary_auto: The G20 summit is supposed to be the pinnacle of multilateralism: the idea that nations can co-operate, compromise and co-ordinate for the greater good. But a lot has changed in the past two decades.

items.title: Blue Jays logo on display at Japan boxing match, without apparent MLB sign-off
items.summary_auto: The Toronto Blue Jays logo was on display during a major boxing match in Japan on Monday, leaving some sharp-eyed viewers intrigued and Major League Baseball (MLB) possibly miffed.

items.title: Family distraught as Manitoba refuses to pay for treatment of 30-year-old with degenerative disease
items.summary_auto: Tears gathered in Jeremy Bray’s eyes as he absorbed the news that his pleas for Manitoba’s government to cover his life-sustaining treatment hadn’t changed the health minister’s mind.

items.title: Family distraught as Manitoba refuses to pay for treatment for 30-year-old with degenerative disease
items.summary_auto: Tears gathered in Jeremy Bray’s eyes as he absorbed the news that his pleas for Manitoba’s government to cover his life-sustaining treatment hadn’t changed the health minister’s mind.

items.title: San Diego Zoo's oldest resident, a Galapagos tortoise believed to be about 141, dies
items.summary_auto: Galapagos tortoise Gramma, who was believed to be about 141 years old, has died at the San Diego Zoo, according to zoo officials. She was their oldest resident.

items.title: #TheMoment firefighters freed an eagle stuck in a tree
items.summary_auto: Tim Cyr tells The National about the moment he and the Squamish Fire Department helped free an eagle that had a wing stuck in a tree.

items.title: BBC leaders grilled by lawmakers after Trump threatened to sue public broadcaster
items.summary_auto: The BBC's chairman acknowledged Monday that it was too slow in responding to allegations of bias over a misleading edit of a speech by U.S. President Donald Trump, but rejected claims that the broadcaster's impartiality was being undermined from within its own board.

items.title: Manitoba, Canada took part in 'intentional destruction' of Red River Métis culture via Sixties Scoop: lawsuit
items.summary_auto: The Manitoba Métis Federation is suing the provincial and federal governments after the Red River Métis were largely excluded from a class action settlement for Sixties Scoop survivors.

items.title: Celebrated author Thomas King expects 'firestorm' as he reveals he's not Indigenous
items.summary_auto: In an essay titled "A most inconvenient Indian" for the Globe and Mail, the Guelph, Ont.-based King says he learned of rumours several years ago that questioned his heritage. The California-born King says he made a concerted effort this year to find their origin, which brought him to a U.S. organization called Tribal Alliance Against Frauds.

items.title: Controversial aid group set up in Gaza as alternative to UN to cease operations
items.summary_auto: The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation, set up to distribute aid to Gaza as an alternative to the United Nations — but which Palestinians said endangered the lives of civilians as they tried to get food — said Monday it would shutter operations.

items.title: Why experts say a white nationalist rally in London, Ont., this past weekend won't be the last
items.summary_auto: An apparent white nationalist demonstration on a busy overpass near London, Ont. 's downtown on Sunday afternoon is concerning for witnesses and experts who track extremist behaviour.

items.title: New Quebec secularism bill to ban prayer in schools, restrict offering of religion-based meals
items.summary_auto: The Quebec government plans to enact a series of measures expanding its secularism rules across public institutions, including a ban on prayer rooms in universities and CEGEPs and restricting the offering of religion-based meals.

items.title: Calgary genealogy society working to uncover secrets of thrift store mystery box
items.summary_auto: A photograph from a telegraphers union meeting. An Italian restaurant menu from Toronto. A newspaper clipping covering a graduating class of Royal Canadian Air Force engineers. What do all those have in common? That’s what researchers with the Alberta Family Histories Society are looking to uncover after receiving a mysterious box from a thrift store.

items.title: Second grizzly bear captured in Bella Coola after attack, B.C. conservation officers say
items.summary_auto: B.C. conservation officers say a second grizzly bear has now been captured in Bella Coola, though it has not been established whether the animal was involved in last week’s attack on an elementary school group.

items.title: Elementary school student dead, another injured after firearm shot in small Quebec town
items.summary_auto: A minor died and another was seriously injured by a firearm late Sunday afternoon in the municipality of Saint-Vallier in Bellechasse, Que., located across the St. Lawrence River from Quebec City.

items.title: Some Pfizer COVID vaccines in short supply at pharmacies across Canada
items.summary_auto: Pfizer Canada says it has placed temporary limits on community pharmacy orders of a COVID-19 vaccine.
